see the Novell Documentation Web page.

preface.title: About This Manual
preface.para: This manual provides getting-started information for new users of &product;. It provides a more detailed version (more pictures and explanatory text) of the information provided in the &product; Quick Tips.
This guide is intended for all &product; users.
This manual provides information about the following:

listitem.para: &product; concepts and definitions
Navigation
Getting-started procedures
Glossary

preface.para: This manual uses the following conventions:
A greater-than symbol (>) is used to separate actions within a step and items in a cross-reference path.
A trademark symbol (®, ™, etc.) denotes a Novell trademark. An asterisk (*) denotes a third-party trademark.

When a single pathname can be written with a backslash for some platforms or a forward slash for other platforms, the pathname is presented with a backslash. Users of platforms that require a forward slash, such as Linux or UNIX, should use forward slashes as required by your software.

entry.para: Click the Add Document menu item.
References to toolbar items, links, menu items, and buttons are presented in italic font.
Text that you must type and file names are presented in Courier font.

preface.para: We want to hear your comments and suggestions about this manual and the other documentation included with this product. Please use the User Comments feature at the bottom of each page of the online documentation, or go to www.novell.com/documentation/feedback.html and enter your comments there.
For the most recent version of the &product; Installation and Configuration Guide, visit the Novell Web site.
You may find more information in the &product; documentation, which is accessible from links within &product;:

listitem.para: &product; Help system
&product; Quick Start Guide
&product; Installation and Configuration Guide

preface.para: The &product; online documents may be found from within the &product; Help system. To access the &product; Help system, after logging in (described later in this manual), click the Help icon.
In the &product; Help system, click the Getting Started Manuals link to access copies of the online documents listed above.

chapter.title: Understanding &product;
chapter.para: &product; is collaboration software that bridges the gap between teammates working alone at their computers and working together during meetings. It provides spaces and tools for online teaming and conferencing.
This chapter provides overview information about the product and about navigating its pages. If you prefer to “learn by doing,” you may want to begin by reading the next chapter.

sect1.title: &product; is Collaboration Software
sect1.para: Collaboration using &product; facilitates online work, creating a “virtual meeting space.”
Here are examples of the increase in team synergy you experience when using &product;:

listitem.para: You and your teammates can work together without having to be in the same room or working at your computers at the same time. Someone can post a note or document to a folder, and, at their convenience, teammates can comment on the work, review and edit files, and further develop the idea. With &product;, teamwork is ongoing and potentially never ending.

When you are working online at the same time, the presence feature of &product; allows you to see which teammates are currently online, and allows you to start a &conf_prod_name; chat session, create an online meeting, make a Skype phone call, and so on.

Ideas are formed together, interactively, with your teammates. By the time you hold that meeting in the conference room, the team has already been a part of the formation of the idea, and teammates are more likely to understand it, buy into it, and assist with its implementation. &product; becomes a "pre-meeting" meeting.

Documents are reviewed earlier in the process, allowing easier modifications and adjustments. &product; also makes it easier for more than one person to write a document, because of workflow processes that automate drafting and review, and because of &product; access control.

Your collaborative process is preserved and publicly accessible in &product;. No more searching through email folders in a frantic effort to "catch someone up" on a lengthy email discussion. To review past discussions and decisions, or to review a previous version of a document, use the powerful search capability of &product; to locate historical information quickly and easily.
Use various &product; tools in combination - a milestones folder, tasks, workflow, discussions, chat, online meetings - to track progress against goals for multiple teams working on a large project.

sect2.title: &product; is Knowledge Management Software
sect2.para: The out-of-the-box &product; tools alone provide powerful enhancements to online collaboration. In addition, enhanced design and use of the workspaces and tools within the product provide additional power that falls under the category of knowledge management. This power involves the intelligent development, management, access, and distribution of organizational knowledge.
Consider the following examples:

listitem.para: When people use their personal workspaces to provide detailed information about themselves, the purpose of the workspace moves beyond merely contact data (phone number, email address, &conf_prod_name; username). It enables searches for various subject-matter experts. Also, &product; breaks down search results, telling you which people and folders are most relevant to the items matching your search criteria. It is easy to see pockets of expertise associated with your area of interest.
Experts can rate entries in &product; using a five-star rating system (one star indicating the least impressive, and five stars being the most impressive).

&product; provides tools - wikis (information coauthored by all participants), blogs (chronological journal entries allowing for comments from readers), workflow (an online representation of a business process), and tags (categorical labels applied to items) — which people can use to create and organize information organically, over time, in ways that map best to the team’s natural work style.

&product; provides work-area snapshots, called accessories, that provide a summary snapshot into a potentially large amount of information, highlighting the most relevant information. For example, the accessory can present entries submitted by an expert on a given subject matter, or it can summarize task-completion information by providing a milestones overview.

sect1.title: Navigating &product;
sect1.para: Your administrator provides you with the web address (URL) used to access &product;, and your &product; username and password.
After you sign in, you see a portal page, as shown on the following page.

A portal page is a web page that presents different applications in subsections within the page. On the Internet, you may have seen pages (for example, Google and Yahoo) that have subsections presenting a weather report that is local to your area, stock quotes that are of interest to you, the local time, and more.
Within the portal page, separate applications can run within sections called portlets. The following picture shows two highlighted portlets on the page:

sect2.title: The Default &product; Portlets
sect2.para: By default, when you sign in for the first time, &product; presents four portlets:

formalpara.title: The welcome portlet
formalpara.para: — Provides quick access to getting-started PDF manuals or to a getting-started web page.

formalpara.title: The navigation portlet
formalpara.para: — Gives you quick access to any workspace or folder you want to view in &product;, to your personal workspace or to your favorite places, to items that match search criteria, or to get Help for the current page.

formalpara.title: The buddy-list portlet
formalpara.para: — Displays the presence of people you designate as your buddies, and provides tools you can use to contact your buddies.

formalpara.title: The bookmark portlet
formalpara.para: — Provides links to important workspaces and folders, and can provide a count of new or changed entries in folders.

sect2.para: &product; provides additional portlets that you can add to your portal page. To add another portlet, click the Add Content link, as follows:
The portal software displays a list of all available portlets. Click the &product; link to see a list, which includes the non-default &product; portlets, as follows:

formalpara.title: Blog summary
formalpara.para: — Provides a snapshot of journal entries from a blog of your choice within the &product; installation.

formalpara.title: Guestbook summary
formalpara.para: — Provides a snapshot of entries from your choice of &product; guest book.

formalpara.title: Photo gallery
formalpara.para: — Presents pictures from a your choice of &product; photo gallery.

formalpara.title: Search
formalpara.para: — Presents items, potentially anywhere within &product;, that match search criteria.

formalpara.title: Wiki home page
formalpara.para: — Displays a summary of the home page of an &product; wiki forum.

formalpara.title: Workspace tree
formalpara.para: — Allows you to go to any place you want within &product;. (The navigation portlet also contains a workspace tree.)

sect2.title: The Navigation Portlet
sect2.para: Here is a picture of the navigation portlet:
The navigation portlet provides the following tools:

formalpara.title: My-workspace icon
formalpara.para: — Displays your personal workspace, which contains your contact information, pictures, a personal blog, and much more.

formalpara.title: Favorites icon
formalpara.para: — Displays a tool you can use to list links to your favorite workspaces and folders, and to access them quickly.

formalpara.title: Search
formalpara.para: — Allows you to perform different types of searches, either for any times or for specific items (people, places, and tags, which are categories that you and your administrators apply to items in &product;).

formalpara.title: Help
formalpara.para: — Provides access to the getting-started PDF books, and provides Help on various sections of the portal page.

formalpara.title: My-teams drop-down list
formalpara.para: — Lists links to all of the workspaces and folders in which you are designated as being a team member.

formalpara.title: Workspace tree
formalpara.para: — Allows you to go to any workspace or folder within the &product; installation. Clicking a plus sign ( +) expands a portion of the tree, and clicking a minus sign ( -) hides that portion of the hierarchy.

sect2.para: Notice the items in the workspace tree. By default, there are four workspaces in the tree. Workspaces are starting places for individuals and teams who want to do a certain type of work. By default, there are four organizational workspaces in the workspace tree: the Workspaces page, and subworkspaces entitled “Global workspaces,” “Personal workspaces,” and “Team workspaces.”

Global workspaces are containers for information available to anyone in your organization. Personal workspaces are pages that of personal information (such as contact information, a personal blog, a personal calendar, and more) for everyone in your organizaiton. Team workspaces are work areas specific to teams within your organization.

sect2.title: Viewing a Workspace or Folder
sect2.para: There are numerous ways to view a workspace or folder in &product;. When getting started, the two most common methods are using the workspace tree or the search tools, both of which are located in the navigation portlet.

For example, you can click on plus sign ( +) next to the Team workspaces link in the workspace tree to see available team workspaces. Using our sample installation, clicking on the plus sign next to the Team workspaces link causes the workspace tree to appear as follows:

The “Team workspaces” workspace contains a single subworkspace, whose title is “ &product; Admin Issues.” Again, using our example installation, clicking on the plus sign next to “ &product; Admin Issues” workspace title displays the contents of that workspace, as follows:

The “ &product; Admin Issues” workspace contains three folders. Folders can, in turn, contain subfolders, which further organize information. None of the folders in the previous picture contain subfolders.

To view a folder, click its linked title. In the last picture, if you click on the Discussion link in the “ &product; Admin Issues” workspace, &product; leaves the portal page and displays the Discussion folder in its own page in your browser window, as shown on the following page.
Notice that &product; displays most of the navigation-portlet tools at the top of the workspace or folder page:
By default, a folder lists only a summary of the discussion entries. To view the entire entry, click the title of the entry, as shown on the following page.
By default, &product; displays the discussion entry as an overlay, on top of the current page, as follows:

sect2.title: Using Tabs
sect2.para: When displaying workspace and folder pages, &product; uses tabs to organize your work. Also, &product; also provides quick access from anywhere in the product to any other place. This picture shows the folder tab and the workspace tree:

&product; creates a tab that is named using the title of the currently displayed folder (“Discussion”). If you click on items in the workspace tree, &product; opens the new place in a separate tab. So, for example, if you click this link:
&product; displays the personal workspace page in a new tab, as shown in the picture on the next page. To delete a tab, click the Close icon ( X) in the upper-right corner of the tab.

sect2.title: Returning to the Portal Page
sect2.para: To return to the portal page you saw when you first signed in, click either the portal-page home link or the left-arrow icon on the workspace or folder page. In the example, the portal-page home link is “Home,” but your administrator may rename it. Consider the following:

sect1.title: Using &product; Help
sect1.para: &product; has a fun and unique way of helping you to learn about product pages and tools. The portal page and all pages that include the navigation bar include a Help icon, as follows:
When you click this icon, &product; dims the page and presents information icons ( i) next to each section of that page for which there exists Help information, as follows:

Click the information icon over the portion of the page about which you want more information. When you do, &product; displays a panel of information. When you are finished reading the panel, click the Close icon ( X) in the upper-right corner of the panel to close it. The picture on the following page shows a panel of Help information and its Close icon.
Some Help topics have more than one page of information. To move to and from pages in a Help topic, you can use the linked numbers and arrows at the bottom of the page, as follows:

The Help topic in the previous picture has three pages. Either click the number of the page you want to view, or click the double-right arrow to move forward, and the double-left arrow to move backward through the topic.

You might find that you want more room on the page to click information icons. If you choose, you can minimize the Help-mode control panel. To do so, click the right-arrow icon, as shown on the following page.
After you minimize the control panel, it appears as follows:

To view getting-started PDF manuals, click View manuals in the control panel. To exit Help mode, either click the Close icon ( X) in the control panel, or click anywhere on the page other than the control panel or a Help panel. Consider the following:

chapter.title: Getting Started
chapter.para: This chapter provides procedures for new users who are learning how to use &product;.
This chapter contains the following information:

sect1.title: Set Up Your Buddy List
sect1.para: One of the most powerful tools in &product; is the presence icon. This icon tells you whether a person is online or not, and enables quick communication with that person (sending an instant message using &conf_prod_name;, initiating an instant meeting using &conf_prod_name;, sending email, placing a call using Skype, and so on).
To take advantage of the presence indicator, you can set up the buddy-list portlet, so that you see presence indicators for your buddies as soon as you sign in.
To set up your buddy list, do the following:

listitem.para: Sign in with your username and password.
Locate the &product; Buddy List portlet.

If you do not see the portlet, click Add Content in the upper-right corner of the portal page, click &product;, click &product; Buddy List, and click Finished. &product; adds the buddy-list portlet to the portal page. If you require more assistance, see your &product; administrator.
In the portlet, click Add buddies.
&product; displays the “Configure buddy list” page.
Begin typing the first few letters of either the first or last name of a buddy, and then click their linked name in the drop-down list.

&product; includes the “type to find” feature. As you type characters in some of the text boxes in the product, &product; displays a list of items (in this case, people) that match what you have typed so far. As you type, &product; adjusts the list to continue matching as you type.
Click Apply.
Repeat Step 4 as often as necessary to add all of your buddies.
Click Closed.

sect1.para: &product; displays your buddies in the buddy-list portlet, with a presence icon next to each name. To remove a buddy from the portlet, follow the same steps, view the “Configure buddy list” page, and click the Delete icon ( X) next to the buddy whose name you want to remove from the portlet.
To ensure that the buddy-list portlet is showing you the most up-to-date presence information for your buddies, click Refresh in the portlet.

listitem.para: Here are the descriptions of the presence icons:
Online
Away (recently online)
Offline
Status unknown
To communicate with a buddy, click the presence icon and select a communication method.
To view a buddy’s personal workspace (which includes contact information), clicked the linked name of your buddy.

sect1.title: Modify Your Personal Workspace
sect1.para: As your next step, create a fun personal “home” page within &product;.

sect2.title: Add Basic Information
sect2.para: To edit and add contact information and other basic information, do the following:

listitem.para: On the portal page, click the “My workspace” icon in the navigation portlet.
Click Manage this workspace > Modify this workspace.

&product; displays a form that allows you to add a personal description to your personal workspace. Consider composing a welcome message for those visiting your page. You can also select a different icon for display in the workspace tree next to the link for your personal workspace tree.
Click OK.

sect2.title: Edit Contact Information and Add Pictures
sect2.para: Do the following:

listitem.para: Click the Modify profile button, as shown on the next page.
&product; displays a form that allows you to alter contact information and upload pictures.
Alter any contact information that is missing or incorrect.
Click the Browse button to upload a picture.
&product; places the filename of the picture in the “Current pictures” section of the page. Repeat this step until you have uploaded all the pictures you want into your personal workspace.

sect2.para: &product; displays the first picture in your list as the main picture in your personal workspace, and displays all other pictures as thumbnails (smaller versions) in a bar below the contact information, as follows:

listitem.para: You may add as many pictures as you like, but you must add them one by one.
On the form used to upload pictures, click the up-arrow and down-arrow icons to move the picture up or down in the list.

When viewing any personal workspace, move your cursor over the thumbnail pictures in the bar below the contact information, and &product; displays that picture as the main picture in the contact-information section.
Click any of the pictures in the personal workspace, and &product; displays a full-size version of that picture.
To delete a picture, view the form used to upload pictures, check the box next to the picture or pictures you want to delete, and click OK.
View your personal workspace page.
In the workspace tree on your personal-workspace page, click the plus sign ( +) next to your name.
Click Blog, as shown in the picture on the following page.
Click New > Blog entry.
Provide a title, and type your journal entry in the Description section.
If you choose, you can click Browse to upload a picture in the Attachments section of the form.
Click OK.

sect1.title: Create a Team Workspace
sect1.para: The sections that follow provide instructions for creating a team workspace.

sect2.title: Ask Your Administrator for a Group Name
sect2.para: Although it is possible to create your team workspace by specifying the names of all team members individually, ask your administrator to create a group name for your team. This facilitates the team-creation process.

listitem.para: From the portal page, in the workspace tree, click Team workspaces.
Click the Add a team workspace button.
Provide a title for your team workspace.
In the “Team members” section, click the “Find groups” text box, type the first few characters of the group name that your administrator created for you, and click the linked group name.

In the “Workspace folders” section, click the check box next to the folders you want to have present when &product; creates the team. (As the owner of this team workspace, you are able to add more folders after workspace creation as well.)
If you choose, you can provide an announcement to be sent to your team members.
Click OK.
View your team-workspace page.
Click Team > Add or delete team members.
In the “Find groups” text box, type the first few characters of your team’s group name, and click the linked name.
Click OK.

sect2.title: View Team Members
sect2.para: By default, &product; includes a team-membership accessory at the top of your workspace page, which shows you the current team membership. If this accessory is not present, do the following to view the team membership:

listitem.para: View your team workspace.
Click Team > Show team membership.

sect1.title: Use Advanced Search to Explore
sect1.para: When you perform a quick search, &product; searches all workspaces and folders. Use the “Advanced search”feature to perform more complex or finely tuned searches. Here is an example of using Advanced search to restrict the scope of the search:

listitem.para: From either the navigation portlet or the navigation bar, in the search section, click Advanced.
Type text that an item must contain, and check the box of one or more workspaces or folders in which to restrict the search. Consider the example in the picture on the next page.
Click Search.

sect1.para: This advanced search returns links to only those items in the Discussion folder (located in the “ &product; Admin Issues” team workspace) that contain the string “legal”. Summaries of items that match the search criteria appear just below the section shown in the previous picture.

sect1.title: Use the Workspace Tree to Explore
sect1.para: In addition to using search to explore workspaces and folders in &product;, you can open the workspace tree in either the navigation portlet or a navigation bar, and you can visit all the places in which you are allowed to visit or participate.

glossdef.para: A list of people that you contact frequently.
An item, such as a wiki topic, file, or photo, that is contained in a folder.
A container for entries and other folders. Each folder has a type, such as blog, wiki, or calendar, that determines its appearance and features.
The state of being connected to a communications service and available for communication. Presence information is indicated by status icons.
A keyword that anyone can add to a place to make it easier to find that and related places. Community tags are shared. Personal tags are private.
A weighted list of tags in which frequently used tags are displayed in larger type.
A container for folders and other workspaces.
